name: Mammals of the United States Online Trivia | Animals by Region | 10 Questions

questions.text: What is the largest member of the weasel family in the U.S.?
questions.explanation:
Wolverine.

	All of these animals are in the weasel family (Mustelidae), but the wolverine is largest.

questions.text: These unusual mammals always give birth to a set of identical quadruplets.
questions.explanation:
Armadillos.

	This is unique among mammals.

questions.text: What is the largest member of the order Carnivora found in the mainland United States?
questions.explanation:
Grizzly bear.

	Grizzlies are members of the order Carnivora, even if they are omnivorous in diet.

questions.text: This endangered mammal lives in prairie dog towns.
questions.explanation:
Black-footed ferret.

	The ferret obtains shelter in the burrows and eats the prairie dogs. Relentless slaughters of prairie dogs have wiped out much of its habitat.

questions.text: What is the largest member of the deer family in the U.S.?
questions.explanation:
Moose.

	All of these animals are members of the deer family.

questions.text: This rodent, also known as a coypu, is not native to the U.S., but colonized many areas after escaping from fur farms.
questions.explanation:
Nutria.

	It resembles a muskrat but isn't closely related. It came from South America.

questions.text: This small member of the canid family is known for its tree-climbing ability.
questions.explanation:
Gray fox.

	Only the grey fox climbs trees.

questions.text: Which of the following animals is not really a rabbit, but is instead a hare?
questions.explanation:
Jackrabbit.

	And the snowshoe rabbit is also really a hare.

questions.text: And how do you tell a rabbit from a hare, anyway?
questions.correct: Baby hares are born with fur
questions.explanation:
Baby hares are born with fur.

	The young of hares are fur-covered at birth, rabbit young are hairless. Rabbits burrow; hares do not. Hares have longer ears than rabbits.

questions.text: This mammal's relatives include the coatimundi, cacomistle, and kinkajou.
questions.explanation:
Raccoon.

	All are members of the order Carnivora, family Procyonidae.
